Based on the current guidance we have received, and Governor Cuomo’s executive orders we are tentatively scheduling our last day of instruction for Friday, June 12. We will be providing an outline next week for the procedures in place for students to receive the remainder of their belongings and for a return of textbooks and Chromebooks.

We continue to make plans for our end-of-year ceremonies and will be releasing details as they are made final. We are partly holding on as long as possible to determine what reopening phase we may be in at the time of the ceremony. We also anticipate our last meal service will be offered around the third week of June. We will be providing more details on this as well pending further guidance.

We appreciate everyone’s patience and understanding as information has been somewhat limited and slow-paced. We remain optimistic as we begin to come out on the recovery side from this pandemic that we will be seeing everyone soon.

There have been numerous developments over the past 24 hours regarding COVID-19 and the need for a complete community effort to mitigate the effects this disease could have on our county. A joint meeting was held this afternoon with the component district superintendents, SLL BOCES, Dana McGuire from St. Lawrence County Public Health, and Dr. Williams from St. Lawrence Health System. It has been decided to close school immediately through April 20 to help prevent the potential spread of COVID-19. Many details are still being worked out and will be made available early in the week.

Madrid-Waddington understands the impact a school closure has on our students, parents, and community so this decision was not made lightly and we truly believe this is the correct course of action. Preventing COVID-19 from becoming a health crisis in this area will take a community-wide effort so we truly appreciate your cooperation and understanding.

Congratulations to senior, Julia Domena, for her outstanding high school swimming career! Julia swims as part of a merger with Canton CSD.

Julia has been swimming on Canton's Varsity swim team since she was in seventh grade. By her freshman year in high school, she became part of 2 Canton record-breaking relay teams. As a sophomore, she became a part of the Section X record-breaking teams in three relays. As a Junior, Julia broke the Canton CSD record for the 100-yeard butterfly. Last weekend at Sectionals, Julia set a Section X record in the 100-yard breaststroke.

Julia will compete with her Canton teammates in the NYSPHSAA swimming championships @ Ithaca College this coming weekend. Congratulations on an amazing high school swimming career, Julia!

post_text: NCSTEP students Keli Kingston and Derek Pelkey completed over 40 hours of summer research in conjunction with an ongoing project at Clarkson University. During the experience, they learned how to code/program and applied that knowledge to create a water clarity pump system used to collect important data for Clarkson's underwater LiDAR Lab. For their culminating activity, Keli and Derek participated in the Clarkson University Research and Project Showcase on August 2, 2019. The pair received the Engineering Design Undergraduate Award for their efforts, which is extra impressive considering they were the only high school students participating in a field of college students. Great job, Keli and Derek!

post_text: As a culmination to Spirit Week last Thursday, the high school students (and staff) participated in the second annual Class Olympics. There were several events, including "Save the Peep," scooter race, sack, and 3-legged race, tug of war, toilet paper squat, scavenger hunt, and egg-and-spoon race. In the end, all had fun, and the Juniors were victorious in this year's annual title. Thanks to Maria Langford for all the great pictures!
